questions.question: What is transmission media in computer networks?

options.text: Transmission media are the protocols that define how two devices agree to communicate.
Transmission media are the logical (IP) addresses used to route packets between networks.
Transmission media are the physical paths that carry electromagnetic signals from one device to another, under the control of the physical layer.
Transmission media are the headers and trailers added during encapsulation.

questions.explanation: Transmission media are the physical pathways that carry signals between devices. The physical layer controls how those signals are sent over the medium.

questions.question: Where are transmission media located in the OSI model?

options.text: Transmission media are located at the data link layer, where MAC addressing is handled.
Transmission media are located below the physical layer and are directly controlled by it.
Transmission media are located at the network layer, where routing decisions are made.
Transmission media are located at the transport layer, where segmentation occurs.

questions.explanation: The lesson explains that transmission media sit below the physical layer and are controlled by it. They are not part of higher layers like data link or network.

questions.question: In what form are signals transmitted through transmission media?

options.text: Signals are transmitted as logical addresses (IP numbers).
Signals are transmitted as application-layer messages only.
Signals are transmitted as electromagnetic energy.
Signals are transmitted as encrypted text by default.

questions.explanation: Signals on a medium are carried as electromagnetic energy (electrical, optical, or radio). This is the fundamental form used to move bits from sender to receiver.

questions.question: How are transmission media classified?

options.text: Transmission media are classified into analog media and digital media only.
Transmission media are classified into guided media and unguided (wireless) media.
Transmission media are classified into baseband and broadband only.
Transmission media are classified into TCP and UDP media.

questions.explanation: The course groups media into guided (signals contained in a physical path) and unguided/wireless (signals propagated through air). This is the primary classification used in the lesson.

questions.question: What is guided transmission media?

options.text: Unguided media broadcasts signals through the air without a conductor.
Guided media provides a physical conduit from one device to another where signals are directed and contained.
Guided media is any medium that uses only light waves.
Guided media is defined as the OSI physical layer itself.

questions.explanation: Guided media provides a physical conduit (like copper or fiber) that contains and directs the signal. This contrasts with wireless transmission where signals spread through open space.

questions.question: What is unguided transmission media?

options.text: Unguided media provides a protected physical conduit where signals are contained.
Unguided (wireless) media transports electromagnetic waves without a physical conductor, broadcasting signals through the air.
Unguided media is limited to coaxial cable used for cable TV networks.
Unguided media requires BNC connectors and terminators.

questions.explanation: Unguided media transmits electromagnetic waves without a physical conductor. Because signals are broadcast through the air, they can be received by any device tuned to them.

questions.question: On what factors does transmission capacity depend?

options.text: Transmission capacity depends on the distance between devices and whether the medium is point-to-point or multipoint.
Transmission capacity depends only on the connector type (RJ-45 vs BNC).
Transmission capacity depends only on the OSI layer used by the application.
Transmission capacity depends only on whether the signal is encrypted.

questions.explanation: Transmission capacity depends mainly on the distance and whether communication is point-to-point or multipoint. These factors influence attenuation, interference, and sharing of the medium.

questions.question: What is twisted pair cable?

options.text: Twisted pair is a glass or plastic core surrounded by cladding that guides light by reflection.
A twisted pair cable consists of two insulated copper wires twisted together to reduce electromagnetic interference.
A twisted pair cable is a central copper conductor surrounded by shielding and an outer plastic cover.
A twisted pair cable is a wireless medium that broadcasts through the air.

questions.explanation: Twisted pair is made of two insulated copper wires twisted together. Twisting helps reduce interference while supporting voice and data transmission over its frequency range.

questions.question: Why are twisted pair wires twisted together?

options.text: Twisted pair wires are twisted to minimize electromagnetic interference between adjacent pairs.
Twisted pair wires are twisted to increase the number of available MAC addresses.
Twisted pair wires are twisted to enable total internal reflection of light.
Twisted pair wires are twisted to prevent signal reflection at the end of the cable.

questions.explanation: Twisting the pair reduces electromagnetic interference between adjacent pairs. This improves signal quality by limiting crosstalk and external noise effects.

questions.question: What types of twisted pair cables exist?

options.text: Baseband and broadband.
Single-mode and multimode.
Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP) and Shielded Twisted Pair (STP).
RG-58 and RG-11.

questions.explanation: The lesson identifies two twisted-pair types: UTP and STP. The key difference is whether shielding is added to reduce interference.

questions.question: What are the characteristics of UTP cable?

options.text: UTP has a metal braid/shielding that reduces interference but makes it thicker and harder to handle.
UTP is ordinary telephone wire; it is the cheapest and easiest to install, but it suffers from external electromagnetic interference.
UTP is immune to electromagnetic interference and is typically used for the longest distances.
UTP is designed to carry multiple analog signals at different frequencies simultaneously.

questions.explanation: UTP is inexpensive and easy to install, but it is more exposed to external electromagnetic interference. It is commonly described as ordinary telephone wire in the lesson.

questions.question: What are the characteristics of STP cable?

options.text: STP is ordinary telephone wire; it is the cheapest and easiest to install.
STP is a fiber medium that guides light straight through the center of a very small core.
STP contains metal braid or shielding to reduce interference; it is more expensive and thicker/harder to handle.
STP is a coaxial cable dedicated to only one channel (baseband).

questions.explanation: STP adds metal shielding to reduce interference, but this makes it thicker, heavier, and more expensive than UTP. The tradeoff is better noise protection.

questions.question: What connector is commonly used with UTP cables?

options.text: RJ-45 connector.
BNC T-connector.
SC connector.
ST bayonet connector.

questions.explanation: UTP cabling commonly uses the RJ-45 connector. This is the standard connector interface for many twisted-pair Ethernet links.

questions.question: What is special about the RJ-45 connector?

options.text: It is used at the end of a coaxial cable to prevent signal reflection.
It is designed primarily for single-mode optical fiber systems.
It is a bayonet-style connector developed by AT&T.
It is a keyed connector that can be inserted in only one direction.

questions.explanation: RJ-45 is described as a keyed connector, meaning it fits in only one orientation. This prevents incorrect insertion and pin misalignment.

questions.question: What is coaxial cable?

options.text: Coaxial cable consists of two insulated copper wires twisted together in a spiral pattern.
Coaxial cable is an unguided medium that broadcasts electromagnetic waves through the air.
Coaxial cable has a central copper conductor surrounded by insulation, shielding (foil/braid), and an outer plastic cover.
Coaxial cable is a glass or plastic core surrounded by cladding for guiding light.

questions.explanation: Coaxial cable uses a central copper conductor with insulating layers and shielding (foil/braid), then an outer cover. The shielding acts as protection and as a conductor completing the circuit.

questions.question: Why does coaxial cable resist noise better than twisted pair?

options.text: Because it is always installed as point-to-point, never multipoint.
Because it uses a keyed RJ-45 connector that prevents insertion errors.
Because it uses total internal reflection in a glass core.
Because of its shielded construction (metal foil/braid) that protects against noise.

questions.explanation: Coax resists noise better because its shielded construction blocks external interference. This makes it more noise-resistant than twisted pair in the course.

questions.question: How are coaxial cables functionally grouped?

options.text: Coaxial cables are grouped as UTP and STP.
Coaxial cables are grouped as baseband (single channel) and broadband (multiple analog signals at different frequencies).
Coaxial cables are grouped as single-mode and multimode.
Coaxial cables are grouped as simplex and full-duplex.

questions.explanation: Coax is grouped into baseband (single channel) and broadband (multiple analog signals at different frequencies). This functional grouping is highlighted in the lesson.

questions.question: What frequency characteristics do coaxial cables have?

options.text: Coaxial cables operate at lower frequencies than twisted pair to reduce attenuation.
Coaxial cables can only carry light waves and therefore have optical frequencies only.
Coaxial cables operate at higher frequency ranges than twisted-pair cables.
Coaxial cables operate only at the same frequency range as ordinary telephone wire.

questions.explanation: The course notes coax operates at higher frequency ranges than twisted pair. This supports carrying more information than standard telephone cables.

questions.question: What networking standards use coaxial cable?

options.text: 1000Base-T and 10GBase-T.
10Base-2 (Thin Ethernet) and 10Base-5 (Thick Ethernet).
FTAM and X.400.

questions.explanation: The lesson cites coax usage in Thin Ethernet (10Base-2) and Thick Ethernet (10Base-5). These are classic Ethernet standards associated with coaxial cabling.

questions.question: What is the maximum range of 10Base-2 Ethernet?

options.text: 10 meters.
185 meters.
100 meters.
500 meters.

questions.explanation: 10Base-2 (Thin Ethernet) is given as having a 185 m range. This value is explicitly stated in the lesson.

questions.question: What is the maximum range of 10Base-5 Ethernet?

options.text: 185 meters.
50 meters.
1500 meters.
500 meters.

questions.explanation: 10Base-5 (Thick Ethernet) is given as having a 500 m range. This is the maximum segment length described for Thick Ethernet.

questions.question: What connectors are used with coaxial cables?

options.text: BNC T-connectors and BNC terminators.
RJ-45 connectors and patch panels.
SC and LC connectors.
Fiber snap-in connectors only.

questions.explanation: Coax networks use BNC T-connectors and BNC terminators. These are the listed connector types for coaxial Ethernet setups.

questions.question: What is the role of a BNC terminator?

options.text: To branch out a coaxial cable for connection to a device (like a computer).
To prevent signal reflection at the end of the coaxial cable.
To convert electrical signals into light pulses inside a fiber core.
To assign IP addresses and protocol numbers on a network.

questions.explanation: A BNC terminator is placed at the end of a coax cable to prevent signal reflection. Without proper termination, reflections can disrupt communication on the bus.

questions.question: What is optical fiber?

options.text: Optical fiber is a transmission medium that uses light reflection to guide signals through a core surrounded by cladding.
Optical fiber is a copper conductor with foil and braid shielding designed for higher frequencies.
Optical fiber is two insulated copper wires twisted together to reduce interference.
Optical fiber is a wireless medium that broadcasts through open air.

questions.explanation: Optical fiber guides light along a core surrounded by cladding using reflection. The lesson emphasizes this structure and the guiding mechanism.

questions.question: What principle allows light to travel through optical fiber?

options.text: Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection (CSMA/CD).
Packet fragmentation to fit the MTU.
Total internal reflection due to differences in density between the core and the cladding.
Broadband multiplexing of analog signals at different frequencies.

questions.explanation: Light travels through fiber due to total internal reflection caused by the density (index) difference between core and cladding. This keeps light within the core instead of refracting outward.

questions.question: What materials are used for fiber optic cores?

options.text: Copper or aluminum.
Glass or plastic.
Metal foil and braided shielding.
Rubber or PVC only.

questions.explanation: Fiber cores can be made of glass or plastic. The lesson states both materials are used depending on the fiber type and application.

questions.question: What are the main advantages of optical fiber?

options.text: Cheapest option and easiest to install, but suffers from external interference.
Very high data rates, immunity to electromagnetic interference, and lightweight cables.
Best for bus topologies using T-connectors and terminators.
Designed mainly to carry several analog signals at different frequencies simultaneously.

questions.explanation: Fiber offers high data rates, immunity to electromagnetic interference, and low weight. These advantages make it attractive compared to copper media.

questions.question: What are the main propagation modes of optical fiber?

options.text: UTP, STP, and coax.
Multimode step index, multimode graded index, and single mode.
Baseband, broadband, and wireless.
Simplex, half-duplex, and full-duplex.

questions.explanation: The lesson lists three propagation modes: multimode step index, multimode graded index, and single mode. These define how light propagates through the core.

questions.question: What characterizes multimode step-index fiber?

options.text: Gradually decreasing core density from center to edge, reducing distortion.
Constant core density, multiple light paths, and higher signal distortion.
Small core diameter guiding light straight through the center for the fastest transmission.
Central copper conductor with shielding and a plastic cover.

questions.explanation: Multimode step-index has constant core density and multiple light paths, which increases distortion. It is also described as an older fiber technology.

questions.question: What characterizes multimode graded-index fiber?

options.text: Signals are broadcast through the air and can be received by anyone with a receiver.
Core density is constant, causing more distortion due to multiple reflective paths.
Light is guided straight through a very small core with substantially lower density (index of refraction).
Core density decreases gradually from center to edge, which reduces signal distortion.

questions.explanation: Multimode graded-index reduces distortion by having density highest at the center and decreasing toward the edge, refracting light back toward the center.

questions.question: What characterizes single-mode fiber?

options.text: It has a much smaller core diameter and guides light straight through the center; it is the fastest transmission technique.
It uses multiple light paths bouncing off reflective walls and has higher distortion.
It uses a central copper conductor and shielding to resist noise.
It is ordinary telephone wire designed for easy installation.

questions.explanation: Single-mode fiber has a much smaller core and guides light straight through the center, enabling the fastest technique. It also uses a substantially lower density (index of refraction).

questions.question: What is an SC connector?

options.text: SC is a coaxial T-connector used to branch the cable to devices.
SC (Subscriber Connector) is a push/pull style snap-in connector commonly used in single-mode systems.
SC is a terminator used at the end of coax to prevent reflection.
SC is a bayonet-style connector developed by AT&T in the late 1980s.

questions.explanation: SC is a push/pull snap-in Subscriber Connector widely used in single-mode systems. The lesson links its use to performance in newer network applications.

questions.question: What are the advantages of SC connectors?

options.text: SC connectors are described as low cost, durable, high performance, and easy to use.
Highest shielding against electromagnetic noise because of foil and braid layers.
Designed mainly for old coaxial thick Ethernet networks.
Used primarily to support token passing in ring topologies.

questions.explanation: SC connectors are described as low cost, durable, high performance, and easy to use. These characteristics explain why they are common in modern deployments.

questions.question: What is an ST connector?

options.text: ST is a coaxial terminator that prevents reflections at cable ends.
ST is a protocol document in the RFC series.
ST (Straight Tip) is a quick-release bayonet-style fiber connector developed by AT&T.
ST is a keyed RJ connector used with twisted pair cables.

questions.explanation: ST is a Straight Tip connector with a quick-release bayonet mechanism developed by AT&T. It is used in both short-distance and long-line systems per the lesson.

questions.question: When were ST connectors most commonly used?

options.text: ST connectors were introduced as the newest connector for modern single-mode systems.
ST connectors were predominant in the late 1980s and early 1990s.
ST connectors were used primarily for 10Base-2 coaxial networks in the 2000s.
ST connectors were most common before Ethernet existed.

questions.explanation: The lesson notes ST connectors were predominant in the late 1980s and early 1990s. This places their peak usage period historically.

questions.question: What other fiber optic connectors exist?

options.text: RG-58 and RG-11.
LC (Lucent Connector) and FC (Fixed Connection).
BNC and RJ-45.
Baseband and broadband.

questions.explanation: The lesson lists LC (Lucent Connector) and FC (Fixed Connection) as other connector types. These are presented alongside SC and ST in the connector overview.

questions.question: What is the main difference between guided and unguided media?

options.text: Guided media always uses light; unguided media always uses copper.
Guided media uses physical boundaries; unguided media transmits through open space (air) without a conductor.
Guided media is defined by TCP; unguided media is defined by UDP.
Guided media is for LANs only; unguided media is for WANs only.

questions.explanation: Guided media is bounded by a physical medium, while unguided media transmits through open space without a conductor. This is the core distinction made in the summary.

questions.question: What is the key advantage of optical fiber over twisted pair and coaxial cable?

options.text: Much higher bandwidth, immunity to interference, and longer transmission distances.
Lower cost and easier installation than twisted pair.
Requires BNC T-connectors and terminators for every connection.
Designed mainly for carrying several analog signals at different frequencies simultaneously.

questions.explanation: Compared to twisted pair and coax, fiber provides much higher bandwidth, immunity to interference, and longer distances. These advantages are explicitly contrasted in the review content.
